Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2013 04:30AM gemini4 wrote: Funny you all mention missing the friends you see at rads every day.  I'm exactly halfway through treatment (today was 15 of 30), and my routine of going to the hospital each morning is ... dare I say it? ... almost pleasant!*  While I am looking forward to being finished with treatment, I think there will be a bit of adjusting once I no longer have to go every day.  There's something kind of nurturing about the environment at my hospital's rads center.  And I don't even have fellow patients before and after me (at this point) with whom I'm bonding; just the nurses, technicians, and RO. * Disclaimer -- my hospital is three miles from my house, and (even with morning rush-hour traffic) a 15-minute drive at most ... plus I have free, designated parking a few steps from the entrance to the rads oncology center ... and there's a little fridge with water, juice, and a basket of snacks (including my favorite Kashi granola bars) ... and once a week there's a massage therapist on hand to give us rads patients free 15-minute sessions.  So there's a lot to like.  :-)
Posts.Title: A rad onc weighs in on radiation "burns" Spinnerpom 53nancy

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2013 07:14AM gemini4 wrote: I have a hard time telling my tattoos apart from freckles and sunspots on my chest!
Posts.Title: A rad onc weighs in on radiation "burns" Spinnerpom 53nancy

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2013 05:01AM gemini4 wrote: I'm exactly halfway through treatment (today was 15 of 30).  I have felt good, energy-wise, since I have been mindful of my water intake (made a huge difference in the beginning!) and have been doing qi gong movement (it's the foundation of tai chi) and have had acupuncture treatments. However, last week I started to develop a very itchy, bumpy rash on my chest.  My RO said it's rads-induced folliculitis.  I have been prescribed a regimen of 3x daily washing of the area with diluted Hibiclens + a mild steroid cream (can't remember the name right now) twice daily.  RO and nurse looked at it again today, because it was driving me crazy over the weekend.  I will admit I have not been good at using the wash and cream more than once daily.  RO also suggested I use a cold washcloth compress over the area after the Hibiclens and before the steroid cream to help calm things down.  I'm trying to leave it alone, but believe me, I'm fantasizing about rubbing a rough, dry washcloth over the area!  (Of course I won't ... but still! ...) I just hope this area calms down soon, otherwise it's going to be a long and uncomfortable three weeks ahead.
Posts.Title: Radiation side effects cooper1988 LibraryLynn

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2013 08:24AM gemini4 wrote: Ps wanted to add about Good Friday being your last day -- I considered rads my Lenten offering! ;-) (My last day is 3/25, day after Palm Sunday.)
Posts.Title: Radiation side effects cooper1988 LibraryLynn

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2013 08:22AM gemini4 wrote: Numbersinger, I developed the itchy rash at around the same point where you are now. At times I want to scratch myself so badly! Sometimes I have to compromise by rubbing the area. I know I should leave it alone but it's nearly impossible at times. My RO said it's folliculitis from the rads. I was given a chlorhexedine wash to use thrice daily (this kills yeast and bacteria that can cause itchiness) plus a mild rx steroid ointment. Kind of helps but not completely. Hopefully you'll respond better! Also for relief from the heat and itchiness, a cold wet washcloth compress on the chest is helpful. Don't use anything as strong as ice; I just keep rinsing the cloth to keep it cold. Hope you feel better soon!
Posts.Title: Radiation side effects cooper1988 LibraryLynn

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2013 07:26AM gemini4 wrote: That article is wacky. I almost had to check the URL to make sure I wasn't reading The Onion. :-) I'm not going to defend People magazine, but I think this statement is entirely wrong: "But the smoking gun is the fact that Angelina Jolie's seemingly spontaneous announcement magically appeared on the cover of People Magazine this week -- a magazine that is usually finalized for publication three weeks before it appears on newsstands." So by that logic, tragic events like hurricanes, tornadoes, mass shootings, (not to mention celebrity breakups!) must also have been presaged three weeks prior to publication? Phew, so glad to have that clarified, because I've always marveled at the People mag covers in the supermarket checkout lines that feature events that happened just days ago. ;-)
Posts.Title: Angelina Jolie's prophylactic surgery JoanQuilts SusansGarden

Posts.Content: gemini4 wrote: I had a checkup today with the breast surgeon. Uneventful until the end when she told me my next mammogram will be in November, which will be a year after the mammo that led to the diagnosis. Six month later (May of 2014) I'll have an MRI. She said I'll be checked every six months, alternating mammo with MRI. I could swear, however, that she told me when I met with her in January that my next mammo would be this June. She said today that that wouldn't be true, since it's too soon after rads. Since all three docs are at the same hospital, I paid the RO nurse a quick visit and left word with her to check with the RO. I know I didn't dream this ... One of the three docs said I'll have a mammo in June (of this year) and MRI in December. The thought of waiting till November makes me a little uneasy ... Mostly for the unaffected breast. When did you ladies have your first mammogram after you completed rads? Age 48 at Dx, pre-menopause / OncoType score 16, no chemo Dx 12/7/2012, ILC, 1cm, Stage IB, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 12/19/2012 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Surgery 1/14/2013 Lumpectomy: Left Radiation Therapy 2/10/2013 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 4/3/2013 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Timeframe between rads and mammogram? gemini4 gemini4

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2013 11:20AM gemini4 wrote: Thanks for the reply, dltnhm.    I just got a call from my RO's nurse.  The RO agrees with the breast surgeon on this timeframe.  At least I will be seeing one of my doc's every three months and will get a clinical breast exam each time.  Given than my original BC was found on a self-exam (barely showed up on mammo but was clear on MRI), probably feeling is more accurate than seeing. Did anyone w/ LX and rads have a different timeframe?
Posts.Title: Timeframe between rads and mammogram? gemini4 gemini4

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2013 07:40AM gemini4 wrote: Hmm. Well I might press for a mammo sooner that November, which would be eight months after rads ended. From an emotional perspective I would rather not go in for a mammo at the same time of year of the original diagnosis. I'd rather mark that time of year with something else. The mammo happened the Monday after thanksgiving and two days after my daughter's birthday (but I had felt the lump and had seen my primary doc so I was worried during the holiday weekend). Then the biopsy was done the day before my husband's bday and dx came back hours before his bday dinner outing. I know there are guarantees. But I can't imagine the team won't agree to push it to a month or so earlier. I know insurance companies can be strict about mammos being exactly a year apart but in my case I'm going to need them every six months.
Posts.Title: Timeframe between rads and mammogram? gemini4 gemini4

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2013 10:32AM gemini4 wrote: Chrisesta67, so sorry to hear of your diagnosis. Does your breast center have a care coordinator/counselor? If so, this would be the person to line up help for you to deal with your emotional needs and support at this time. I see you're also in Massachusetts -- if you're in the Boston area, feel free to PM me if you have questions about your hospital. ((Hugs)) to you.
Posts.Title: Treatment plan moving fast Chrisesta67 gemini4

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2013 01:32PM gemini4 wrote: I do think it's possible to be feeling something early on.  I'm on Day 3 and have definitely felt heat coming from my chest, and my RO even noticed that my chest is looking red.  I'm not particularly fair (I'm a brunette who tans easily), but I do have some psoriasis/eczema on my chest which might be making it more sensitive. I have also been feeling queasy and overall lousy (dull headache).  My RO today said it sounds like I'm dehydrated, so I'm trying to remember to drink much more water than I usually do.  Carolyn, psychosomatic or no, symptoms are symptoms!  If you feel crummy, it's because you do.  I hope that makes sense!  ;-) Jabal and Carolyn, I hope you both start feeling better.
Posts.Title: only second treatment and..... jabal gemini4

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2013 03:29PM gemini4 wrote: Hi ladies! I had my 30th and final this past Monday. Next week I meet with MO for tamoxifen. My skin is feeling pretty good. The "tan" color changes/fades to a different tint each day today. Just had to share this light moment here -- and I hope it's appropriate. Coming out of the shower today I noticed my rads boob is monochromatic -- the nipple is the same color as the skin. It struck me that my boob looks like a Vizla dog's face right now! ;-). (For those not familiar, Vizlas are Hungarian hounds, similar to a pointer. Their coats are a rusty tan color, and their nose is pretty close in color to their fur.)
